text: I was raised in um Western
Massachusetts I am the uh child of two
Southerners my brother is also Southern
and my family um is Southern way back
before the Mayflower so I was the only
yane in the family for all
generations and it um it definitely
shaped me in my taste I was the only
little Yankee boy um who liked boiled
peanuts and puts uh salted peanuts in
his Coke and um liked grits for
[Music]
breakfast well Southerners I think have
um a number of traditions um one of
which is uh storytelling so um my
Southern relations uh when we get
together I mean it's just one story
after another after another after
another Thanksgiving when I go down to
visit my Uncle Bob and aunt reala and
all the cousins are there my stomach
will hurt for days um afterward because
it's just so funny and they're all great
storytellers and that's kind of how uh
family knowledge is passed on from
generation to generation is through
stories um you know I mean it's a
cliche uh but um there's a certain level
of dysfunction I suppose
that um goes along with being part of a
southern family um secrets and and and
all these
entanglements um and there's a uh
there's a sort of gentility courtesy I
mean I was very polite as a child um
very well-mannered as a child and um
that's something else that you find in
the south
[Music]
probably it all started with the with
the Asters you know in the Vanderbilts
in New York City in um the Gilded Age
when Society was constructed of um
layers upon layers upon layers of
etiquette I mean you you didn't call
somebody on the phone or you didn't text
them and say let's go grab lunch you
would have your your person um send your
handwritten note over by Carriage to
your acquaintances of your friend's
house and they would receive the note
and respond in kind and there were just
very um many layers to society and how
we behaved and how we reacted
appropriately now um because New York is
and always has been sort of the uh the
the Zeitgeist from which you know
everything radiates out this is the sort
of The Taste Center and the Design
Center of America um and certainly was
back then
U I think a lot of people emulated uh
that stratified sort of concept of
society and um Chicago certainly did you
know the big families began behaving as
New Yorkers did and then as as Society
spread West it happened in the west
coast as well and down south and it's
interesting because um these these
manners you know a lot of them became of
course outdated over time life became
more casual um you know Casual Friday
took over but in the South what you find
is that these um these
manners uh still remain um last um
Thanksgiving I was driving down a dirt
road in Alabama it was a red clay road
very narrow deep dark Alabama you know
where there are alligators in the
backyard and this big pickup truck like
in Ford F350 was approaching me
and um so it was me and my boyfriend and
our two French bulldogs and I'm thinking
okay this is the part where the good old
boy pulls the over shoots him and
takes the dogs and so as this truck gets
closer and closer it's got the big
headlights you know on the top I see the
driver is wearing camouflage including a
camouflage hat so I'm thinking well this
is it we're going to die and just as we
pass the trucker goes like this
and moves on and I realized at that
moment it was an epiphany and I realized
the last gentlemen these are the last
true gentlemen are the Southern good old
boys because their mamas taught them to
behave you know yes ma'am thank you
ma'am no sir thank you sir and that's
very much how it is in the South and
that's why I love the South I love I
love the South
[Music]
I don't think I've inherited the um you
know the gothic literary sensibility
sort of almost um dated to udor Welty
and flener O Conor it's a it's a South
that doesn't quite exist as it did um
certainly there are uh Pockets um but
because I didn't live in the south I
didn't experience you know the Spanish
moss hanging off the trees and the sort
of
sweltering days that sort of
drowsy you know and the sort the sweet
tea and um I have a deep appreciation
for it I mean one of my favorite authors
is um Carson McCullers and I think um
the member of the wedding is just one of
the most perfect books ever written um
and it really for me captures that
flavor um I don't know if you would call
it a Gothic Southern novel but it
certainly captures that deep deep sort
of almost the sensual South The
Melancholy um Quality um So I myself
don't think of myself as a southern
writer although there are certain things
about me that are definitely uh that are
definitely Southern um that are there as
a result of um you know having Southern
parents and having Southern relatives
[Music]
